row.Text: I have the same problem

noted (though personally I think that particular facet of SE site organisation is a bit bonkers, and in hindsight I probably would have asked my question at http://meta.stackexchange.com/ , believing meta.so to be for questions about the original site. Looking for information about 1 site on a second does not make for the most intuitive user experience.
I don't disagree.
Yeah, I was trying to ask before any questions had been made. There weren't any tags =\
Can you post a link to the definition? I think recipes could be a good think so long as they don't get duped over and over again.
I don't disagree. But seeing that 99% of the time these will be beer questions, is it necessary or can it be assumed unless otherwise tagged?
correct, if he said. "I really like Lambic, what steps are different from normal brewing?" for sure, upvote from me.

@Joe if this was the BEER homebrewing site, it could perhaps be assumed. Currently more of the questions are beer related than wine related (I doubt it's as high as 99% personally), but the site is 2 days old in a private beta. Things could change.
I agree. Most micro brewers start as home brewers anyways, so why kick them out when they "cross the line?"
I like that idea. Anyone else?
Yes, I shamelessly cribbed this from the "7 Essentials", but I wanted to get it up here so I could throw out my suggestion.

I agree with Fisttoaster and fearoffours, and I think we need to point out the obligation to use the "beer", "wine", "mead", etc. tags on all questions on our FAQ. Is there a way to get the system to enforce required tags, like it does when you create a meta question? Otherwise I foresee a good deal of ongoing re-tagging.
I agree, especially considering they might have some of the best advice on the site.
What if a question fits into both categories? Then I think you wouldn't use either tag
In that case, what is our mission?
Time to grab another of those 7 essential questions: http://meta.homebrew.stackexchange.com/questions/18/whats-the-elevator-pitch-for-our-site
Yeah, good idea.
+1 seems good to me, it's sure to be a recurring question and as a result should go in the FAQ as well.
We may want an additional CW (or perhaps even one per style) that has "recommended recipes" where you can post recipes you've tried and liked.
What's a CW? BTW, thats what I was expecting when I posted a recipe request for the sour, that any further requests for the same type would be marked dupe and closed.

CW is Community Wiki. I would support reopening your question and making it a CW, perhaps with a rewording to make it more specific to a style, but I'm not sure anyone has enough rep yet to make CWs... sgwill, do you have that ability yet? We definitely need to get this worked out before the public beta starts and get it on the FAQ.
I second that! The more active we are in the beta, the better the site will be when it launches!

Good question. I think we actually would want to use all applicable tags (beer, wine, mead, cider, etc.) for a question that applies to multiple types of fermentables. That way when people narrow down by tag, those questions will still be in their list.
How do we keep the discussions from being too subjective or argumentative?
And remember, your vote limit for homebrewing doesn't carry over to meta, so be active on meta too!
Nice find. I didn't even realize this existed. I really wish I would have known though...
A friend pointed it out to me back when I was promoting HB.SE. I think that there's a lot of value in bringing them in, since they've got a community and we've got a better platform.
Indeed. And if we start getting a lot of question specific only to micro-brewing, we can easily just tag them as such.
+ 1 use your head, we're all (mostly) adults here.

My biggest question is what would be the logistics of this? I think it would be a great jumpstart for the site and both sites have similar DNA, but I wonder how trivial it will be to work through a merger. Having looked at the system dumps from other SE sites and my guess is that it should be very possible to pull the content in here, but I think we'd need some help/advice from meta.meta to understand how/if this might happen.

I think most of us beta users can use our heads, but once we open up to the populace at large, we need to at least have some guidelines in the FAQ. I think Fishtoaster's answer is a good start on what our FAQ entry could look like.

Just discovered most of us have the ability to make community wikis. I think we just need to work out what the FAQ should say, something along the lines of all recipe posts are CW, and only one recipe CW per style.
Awesome! Are any of their users (esp. moderators) in on the private beta?
@Nicholas Trandem: By following the "Guidelines" of Good Subjective, Bad Subjective: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/
@Nicholas Trandem : When the merger happens, there will be no more private beta. To avoid a disruption of service for their current users, we forgo the closed beta period.
Yes, that's what I was afraid of, too. I would rather have more community involvement than some odd standard of 'perfect question.' Hopefully he didn't take it personally.

Sure, 'Policy' probably wasn't the right word. But part of the point of this site is to make the content valuable to the large homebrew community. I agree, I don't want a campaign, but new questions will follow the mold of existing questions; isn't private beta is the time to make general standards, even if we don't 'enforce' them later.

Enforcing a *"questions must be phrased in the affirmative"* policy on the 99.5% of the users who are not privy to these conversations is not good policy. Sure, it might be a *nice* idea and you raised it here; Others can follow your example. But that next step... to "add to the FAQ and edit Questions" is what I am suggesting can become hostile and off-putting to those on the receiving end of that activity.
@Nicholas - Yes, I'm one of their users :-)
I suppose I could see that argument- I saw it more as "What style beer would a person who likes X like" which doesn't seem on-topic for a brewing site.
I agree it should probably be CW.
I disagree with the dual forums, Stackoverflow has shown us that tagging can bridge the gap where there were traditionally different forums
I'm a UX designer, so I do mostly icons and not logos. I could take a stab if others want to throw out some ideas.

Maybe, but if you had separate forums, those interested in either one could easily go to it every day or two and easily read all the headlines of all the active threads, without mucking about with tags. Totally unlike Stackoverflow, which gets a new question every 2 seconds or so.

For the FAQ, perhaps guidance should be: if you see a question that falls under "how do I get away with X without being arrested", flag it for a moderator. If you see a question that is asked innocently, but is illegal in some places, add this important detail to your answer (or as a comment to the question.)

I agree with Joe and disagree with Nicholas. Nicholas - you already put 4 tags in your example and five is the limit (no room for any specific tags.) Additionally, by tagging non-specific topics with a specific tag, you dilute the results of searching for that tag. If I have a generic question about yeast, I believe the tags should simply be "yeast" and anything else specific to the context of my question.

"without mucking about with tags" - You mean typing "wine" in the search or clicking "wine" tag? Also, you may notice that SO figures out which tags interest you and filters & highlights based on this information. "which gets a new question every 2 seconds or so." - isn't that the goal, that the community gets so large that lots of specific and/or esoteric questions on the minutia of brewing are asked? SE was designed to overcome the shortcomings of archaic forums and Q&A sites (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NWHfY_lvKIQ). Applying archaic methods to organization doesn't seem reasonable.
At high enough reputation, there are also wiki functions to solve this.

As mentioned in the "7 Essentials" it would be nice (actually, more important perhaps) to not only get them to mention the site, but to become a user as well. Also, getting well known contest winners and micro-brewery owners as users would help also. I have seen threads on SO where people /freak out/ because someone who wrote a popular library answered a question. It'd be fun, and attract users, if that stuff happened here.
Is this merger going on right now? I see some new users on the site that have a lot of rep and seem to have a rep graph that goes back to earlier this year. Any update on this merger would be nice.
The merger was completed today, pretty much as described here.
Sure, but SO is a techie forum for techie people. I'm quite sure the average winemaker would simply come here, see that the vast majority of the questions were about beer, and then not come back.
We're heeeeeeere. Thanks for taking us on guys! We at BrewAdvice.com are excited to tackle the q&a with you all.
Ah crap- there goes the neighborhood. :P
OK. So my old actions have been rescored with under the new system. Got it. Thanks.
Exactly what I was looking for and couldn't find before asking the question. Thanks!
When I logged in with my openId, it's using a separate account here and homebrew. Is it possible for another mod to merger the two? Thanks
Dammit man, I'm a doctor, not a database admin! (Sorry, don't have that much control)
I like it, but we need to cover both beer & wine. Perhaps add a cork to it as well?
great idea, I'll follow this, and retweet the ones I find really interesting.
I noticed the same issue.
Ok, that makes sense. But then how did @pulsehead get it? (Not to pick on pulsehead, I am just confused how he/she got the badge, since the system thinks he/she has only been a member for 23 days.)
The "member for" doesn't account for the merge. It's a member for date based on this site only.
I follow the same guidelines.
I like to see questions with at least as many votes as answers.

I know I'd like to see more voting happening. There are two many questions with many views and 0 votes. I nee dto be more dilegent about this too. I like Deans general guidelines. I don't have a feel yet for how I have been voting.
Hey Dean, In your example guidlines do you ever NOT vote? And Why?
Chez: Since the site it new I vote liberally. The cases I don't vote usually fail #3 because they aren't relevant *to me*. EG: the threads on chocolate extract and corking beer.
Re: Down voting, definitely leave a comment when you down vote something. -- http://brewadvice.com/questions/663/meta-down-voting
I'm asking about voting on questions, not answers.
Doh! I guess you should also thoroughly read a question before you answer or vote for it.
And now we see the answer voting system in action! (-: You can always add another (more appropriate) answer to a question.
You can also delete an answer, if you don't think it should be around on the site. "Cleanup", if you will.
Though, I'd leave this one as a example :)
Glad to be of service?
Don't forget the features like official "Meta" section and chat! :)
But I don't like making new friends!
@brewchez it's ok, with your rep, you don't have to be nice.
@[everyone else] - kidding about that last comment.
That's a great question to which I don't know the answer. Let me try and find out.
We'll have to manually merge those accounts. Send an email to team@stackexchange.com once we've merged the sites and we can merge your two accounts.
Well, I think it's a good idea, but this comment itself is opinion, and probably so are all possible answers. Is the idea that this doesn't apply to meta?
Seconded. Trust the community.
Agreed whole heartedly. That's what the voting is for, and that's what is supposed to get the cream to the top right???
You've expressed your opinion quite well. The downvote just feels vindictive.

My apologies, it was not meant to be vindictive. It is a function of this format, to downvote is to express disagreement. It was not meant to be personal and if it seemed that way it is a mistake on my part and for that I apologize.
Your link for "service" is bad. It should be http://stackexchange.com, not .org.
thx. fixed link

Thanks Jack. We've had the Google ads up for a while now, and have made about 3 bucks. Direct targeted ads are definitely an idea. I like the ip-targeted LHBS idea, though I don't know that we have the resources to sell those ads. Might have to get you all to do it! :)

I appreciate your honesty. It's true, $129/mo is a crap load, especially with sites like HBT out there. Another option is for us to make our own version of the platform. I still want to hear more ideas, and we have a few of our own kicking around as well, but there is a good chance you're very right. Thanks for the answer!
Your own version would work too. I hope you guys figure it out, good luck!

Man. I didn't realize that Spoolsky and Atwood were charging that much for the platform. Maybe they're open to suggestions about, you know, not charging so much for something that's supposed to be there to help build communities.
There's a big discussion about that on their meta site. They want to keep a barrier to entry up so that people don't just create the sites on a whim. They want real good usage and stuff.
@JackSmith There's a big discussion about that on their meta site. They want to keep a barrier to entry up so that people don't just create the sites on a whim. They want real good usage and stuff.
@TinCoyote At that point, it's worth looking at our own freelance hourly rates and seeing if that's cost-effective. New plan: play the lottery.

As far as stats go, here's some info for you. First link is overall data from official launch through today. http://bit.ly/ck5lJE Next link is sources, same time period http://bit.ly/couroj. If you want to see other stuff, let me know.

Thanks for sharing. Funny in your second capture one of your keyword hits was my post for carabohemia malt. Who is handling your SEO? Seems like hits from searches should be the stronger %age. That's likely a content issue though with such a new site.

We don't really do any SEO. Since we don't have any control over the specific site code, we trust the content / tags to get hits, and we try to spread the word / links / etc as much as possible. The software was inaccessible to google for a while, which didn't help. Should start getting better hits now.
Nice breakdown.
Thanks Dean! That's a great breakdown.
+1 specifically to DIY
Thanks for replying! I had no idea we had some Fog Creek users. I sent you an email, as well. Also, Bootstrap is enabled. We turned it on a couple weeks ago.
I guess that makes sense when you said "I got up to 49 rep with little effort in one morning, but I know the system." Thanks for info Rich :)
I guess what I'm trying to say is RDWHAHB. ;)
Simon, that's an excellent idea! Currently, we don't have the ability to create special badges or or give more points, but I really like this idea. Thanks!
Downvoted because I think this question is discouraging participation, although I respect the poster and his intention to stir discussion.
Point well taken. Thanks for being alive on the site and helping to ensure something happened here over the weekend.

Hey brewchez, maybe no one is asking questions because your answers are so good. I'm teasing, although I do enjoy your answers and questions. I'm new to the site and have been enjoying looking around and feel very comfortable asking questions seeing guys like you and PJ and Dean on here to help us all out. I like this site and its good because of you guys and of course the "laid back" nature of us homebrewers.
Side note, if you get a chance, I'd love to get that Oatmeal Stout recipe from you.

Most of the time I am asking questions just to add content. I usually have an answer in my mind but its nice to see others comments and takes in questions. I started to get tired of answering my own questions though due to inactivity.

I was advertising for a little bit, and it was going well. However, that costs money.
The next step would be to get everyone posting a flier in LHBS and whatnot, and telling their club members, etc.

@PJ Fliers are fine, but come on this is the digital age... You need to be focused on upping how people get here organically. And that's with proper SEO and linking up the content appropriately! I know its was down played in the past, but SEO matters! How many incoming links are there here? How many links on other pages!!! When people search for whirlpool chiller is this site even on the front page of a google search?

One of the characteristics of any brew-informational site, be it in this format or in a forum is that there are going to be TONS of duplicate questions from newbs, and that tends to drive down participation from the more experienced users. I see it all the time on Homebrewtalk. People simply do not do any research to see if there questions have been answered previously.

I aggree with the comments above. I think what should be done is to a)tell our club members about it. If we have already done it, we can do it again. b)Fliers aren't really the right advertising for an forum, since we're talking about internet business the advertising should be done through internet. Write about it in homebrew fora, ask for bloggers to put a link of this on their blogs. I agree about the chaotic situation in most homebrewing fora with the same questions being asked again and again. I think the structure here is way more organised and has potential to become even better.

@brewchez for sure. I'm up for any ideas there are. The google adwords campaign was really successful, I just can't afford to front it, ya know? Maybe we should start a new topic on "ways to get the word out"
I'd love some exposure on HBT Forums, I just don't have the rep over there to post about it and not get shut down.
@PJ Are you actively cruising the blogosphere and asking folks to add brewadvice to their blog roll. Getting those incoming links will continually help your google search scores.

Even SO questions have trouble staying on top in google. How'd you find the site Jim? Did we send you a press release a while ago? I tried to hit up all the examiners. (press release is the second post here: http://blog.brewadvice.com/)

I can't remember exactly how I came across it - must've been during a websearch on brewing stuff. I found it a couple of days ago and made a note to come back and really check it out. Glad I did, hopefully I can help keep it growing! I plan to blog about it tonight, and can do an Examiner article as well...

Thanks for the comment Juanote and your awesome participation since you've joined. One thing about this site is that it's about to be absorbed by the stack exchange platform. So, while we do love running it, it's actually going to be run by the community, assuming we pass the entry. More info: http://area51.stackexchange.com/
Hey, that's cool. I'm curious to see how that works out.
FYI, it's spelled sake. But I still like the idea!
I guess I'll just have to start my own thread for CIDER Stackexchange site?
People seem to be voting up PJs response, but not the question...How does that happen? If you want to see wine, mead and sake vote up the question as well!
Agreed! (Ya, I was the first upvote. What!)

I think this site has attracted questions for all types of brewing so far. I've seen questions on mead, wine, cider, and I think I remember seeing one on spirits. Perhaps the word "Brew" and the brown theme lead people to the conclusion that this site is only for beer brewing, but I've never thought that it was.
What Room3??? People don't use a beer bottle cap for their wines, meads and spirits? I hear you 100%, but I like the little bottle cap hat on the "B" of BrewAdvice.

I like the bottle cap too, but most wine makers use corks, not bottle caps, at least all of the ones I know. I'm just trying to say that although the site has a "beer vibe" to it, it's already open to the community Kyle is trying to promote.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not bashing the bottle cap, I like it too. I'm just saying that we actually already support the community that Kyle is asking about, he just might not realize it at first glance.

@Room3 I agree. If you ask a wine question on here, I don't think you'd get voted down. I think you'd get an answer. But we definitely give off a beer vibe. One thing to think about. If this community were to fully support beer, wine, mead, cider, sake, cheese?, etc., would all the beer questions need a beer tag?

...since we have an active community... I don't really think we are there quite yet. It seems to take a while to see changes and results outside of a small handful of current users. The site is pretty slow most of the time, IMO. I am all for seeing other aspects of home alcohols, lets just be realistic to how long its going to take before a sake person actually answers a question about sake.
@brewchez ya you're right. I meant more that it's not up to Taylor and me to make decisions for the community, as it was when the site first launched.
I tend to whine more than I brew beer too....Oh.
Yes but judging on # of questions and users, this site seems much more active.
Ditto @[Kyle Boon]
It looks like there hasn't been any actual user activity on that site since March 3. Only community admin bot bumps.
I have been wondering how many visitors there really are, because things have seemed to slow down over the past 4-8weeks.
I can give you the actual analytics if you want. But ya, it has slowed down a bit. I had some extra google ad word credits from GoDaddy, so I had those pushing traffic for a little bit too.
Dashboard 1/1/10 - 4/14/10 http://skitch.com/hookedonwinter/n6hn1/dashboard-google-analytics
Dashboard 1/1/10 - 4/14/10 - overall stats - http://skitch.com/hookedonwinter/n6hn1/dashboard-google-analytics
General Traffic Sources 1/1/10 - 4/14/10 - http://skitch.com/hookedonwinter/n6hn2/traffic-sources-overview-google-analytics
If you want to see any other stats, let me know
Thanks for the info.
@brewchez: Sorry, but I think I joined about 4-8 weeks ago. Did I forget to brush my teeth or something? :)
I registered and started adding questions/commenting - but, what is this exactly? If this proposal is accepted, what are the ramifications for brewadvice?

9K and 7 upvotes, wow that is an interesting phenomenon. I would think you give people something to do other than just READ the site and they'd take advantage of it and vote. I mean you read it and that's great, but with the option to vote you can at least feel like you are part of the knowledge base process. Fascinating to me from a behavioral standpoint.

I think a lot of people don't realize they can change their votes.. Like, here's a -1 vote, pending a change. Then turn it into a +1. Or a 0. Whatever... But ya, I'd like to see more votes on here. We have 347 questions on this site. Two of them have 10 votes. One has 9. Three have 8. The rest are lower.

Excellent thoughts. Tell me this, do you also see on SO that as soon as there is an accepted answer people stop answering and/or voting? Almost as if the question is some how closed. This comment is open to Kyle as well.

Ya for sure. I've definitely refrained from accepting an answer right away, both here and on SO, to make sure people would still check it out. I've also changed my accepted answer to a better one before, both on here and SO. But, that's me.
As long as nobody else gets more rep than me I'm okay with it ;-)

They won't. See my account on fogbugz.stackexchange.com. Maybe I'm just used to the unlimited power I have there, but I find the inability to comment or upvote uncomfortable. We're going to keep fogbugz.stackexchange.com in bootstrap until we start seeing behavior that makes us want to disable it. There are still safeguards, even in bootstrap, like link limitations and activity caps. Anyway, take it for what it's worth. I got up to 49 rep with little effort in one morning, but I know the system.
@Rich and now you're about to break 100

You're right. Of course, the worst is when a new user comes on, asks a question, accepts the first so-so answer, and leaves. There's plenty of these and StackOverflow.com, though, and the system is good at burying the less helpful answers over time.
Interesting and thanks for the insight. To the site mods, how fast are new users coming in here anyway???

What would be really cool is a hook into the BrewAdvice vote click that also upvotes the article on BrewPoll. Less confusion for users & more votes for us. Requires that the user also be logged into BrewPoll....
Where do you get the badge code?
I need to write a hop press post, and then I will work on this.
I didn't know we could include our own JS
You can't. But I can edit the js for the site, and have it pick up the flag.
That's what I meant by "we".... It's a community after all. ;-)
ya ya ya. Technically, "I" can't either. But the admin account I have access to can. :)
Tested in FF 3.6, Chrome, Safari. All for Mac.
Going to implement this today. Thanks Dean!
Implemented! And it works great. Thanks for your help Dean!
Just kidding. It replaces html after js is bound, so it essentially unbinds the voting functionality, etc. I found a solution, posting in a sec.
Possibly because it tramples on window.onload, or replaces all of #question.
I would change window.onload = function to jQuery's $(document).ready(function() { <code> } );
I can do that. Any reason?
1. It's not a W3C standard (might not be supported in all browsers). 2. There could be more than one window.onload - only the last one would work.
Cool, I'll do that today.
I don't know that every question should be on brew poll. They might not want us flooding their site with the simple Q&A. What do you think? Testing the new code now.
I don't know that every question should be on brew poll. They might not want us flooding their site with the simple Q&A. What do you think?
Putting the badge up doesn't automatically submit the question. A registered BrewPoll user must do that.
I completely agree.
Can you precede the title with [meta] please?
What does teh [Meta] do?
Designates the question as site related, not beer related
makes sense enough, I'll give it a try.
agreed. Do it..
You failed to mention the lack of trolls and elitist ass-hats on a Q&A site like this. Just sayin' ;)
It's still a young site...

This was supposed to be something of a troll. Well, more like a softball question. (-:
Who's to say I am not an elitist ass-hat?
I'm very resilient to trolls. Bring it. ;)
I have been getting the auto tagging about 50% of the time. I assumed they were tweaking the settings or something over the last couple days.
What browser are you using?
It's definitely a user by user issue. Just checked it again, and it works here: http://skitch.com/hookedonwinter/n2j37/edit
I was seeing it yesterday at work and then again at home. The home PC had to be booted, so the browser was freshly opened.
Might have been a coincidence for me then.
Sadly we don't have any control over the rep rules. We are considering rewriting the software in php so we have total control. Any ideas on how to make the voting more clear?

I wouldn't mess with it. This system works really well for StackOverflow.com with thousands of users. Use the software without modification for a few months to get an appreciation for how good it is.
The FAQ is a good place to explain how voting works. A better "how this site works" document would go a long way.
You're a little closer now. The community will sort it out in time. I think we are at a time when we should encourage participation and be very judicial with the negative points.
With screenshots
We can do something like that on the blog. The FAQs (http://brewadvice.com/faq) don't get into "how" to vote, but do explain a little about voting.
You can't edit the FAQ?
There's a good chance that the server time isn't the same as your time. As a test, it is now 9:38am MST on 2/10/10.
When I look at my messages I see "Showing 2010-02-11 to 2010-02-11 ; current time is 2010-02-11 16:16:44 UTC". Maybe it runs on GMT/UTC
Oddly enough I had trouble finding the RSS Feed on the questions page. I just didn't look hard enough. I think the Twitter solution is really nice though.
I don't know that it's necessary, but promoting the Twitter and RSS more might get people more active on the site. I just wanted some method to keep me abreast of all questions.

At first I thought this answer was not really helpful, since it only dealt with the example given, and not the underlying question. But then I thought more, and since issues of legality are dependent on the laws of your locality, I agree: all questions about the legality of something are 'too localized'.
Well, in that case, how did some of the members get 'member for' several months?
Actually, I do have that much control.

@pkaeding, I got it because I was a member of BrewAdvice. Then I found out about HB.SE.com and created another account. Interestingly enough all my BA questions that were marked as answered on BA had that marking removed on migrating to HB.SE. Annoying, but fixed inside of 10 minutes, so easier to work around than submit a bug.

excellent answer, one rider -- if the keyword is *already* in the title organically, we don't add it. Also, if the community feels the keyword-in-title rule does not work at all, it implies the tagging system is broken, in my strong opinion.
Thanks that's exactly what I was wondering. Is there a limit on the number of tags that are coerced into the title?
Never mind - It's the "most popular tag". Thanks again.
And now, 3 months later, I think time has shown that I was correct. This forum is not being used by winemakers.
Yes it is possible to change your answer. Although how would we ever get the "Populist" badge? :)
Right, a bunch of us came from the old BrewAdvice site.
You'll probably need to put in a request with Atwood or ask about that on meta.stackexchange.com. I don't think we've got the ability to alter those sorts of mechanisms.
Perhaps a moderator could shunt this question over to that site, in stead of retyping.
Asking here is ok.

I've been curious about this as well. Some food pairing questions have been asked, but there's definite gray area between that and the cooking stackexchange. I have also wondered about things like appropriate glassware.
Presumably, this was covered in the proposal phase of the SE, but I wasn't around then, so it may not have been.

Agreed, I'd never seen that. I personally agree with the sentiment, though at this phase, I'd feel the need to err on the side of allowing anything that might help the site get off the ground. That being said, I don't think including distilling would help the site grow in a coherent way.
@mlusby yes, allowing distilling seems to bring as many cons as pros.. maybe more.
Looks good, thanks PJ!!
Ignoring legality, what cons are there?
Of course, if it's a simple direct question (what temperature is boiling at my elevation), then a simple answer could be accepted quickly.
@pj I'd still wait a day as a courtesy to anyone else interested in answering .. that's a rule of thumb
More like a rule of wrist... i kid. sounds good!
I'm burning through my 5 flags every day and there are still dozens of spam answers. Is there a way to prevent users with low reputation (or new users) from including links in answers?
@Hopwise: well, that's where a moderator should step in... They can destroy an entire user and all its posts with two clicks. Which I've now done for the users you've flagged. Thanks!
Ok, thanks. In the future I'll only flag one answer per user.

Here is the [BATF FAQ on distilled spirits](http://www.ttb.gov/spirits/faq.shtml). The BATF does issue permits for Distilled Spirits Plants (DSP). You can check out all the hoops you need to go through to get one [here](http://www.ttb.gov/spirits/regs/27cfrpart019.htm)[The applications are here](http://www.ttb.gov/applications/dsp_beverage_packet.shtml).

Sanitizing and Sterilizing are different. Sanitizing reduces micro-organisms to an acceptably low level. [Sterilization](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sterilization_%28microbiology%29) is to remove them all. When I can, I sterilize my bottles using dry heat in the oven. If I don't have time, I fall back to soaking them in sanitizer for several minutes.

Which is more logical to go with? I would *guess* that most people just sanitize their equipment most of the time, but of course sterilizing is the ideal. Sanitizing seems better to me - I don't think most people, if asked, would say they wanted equipment they could actually literally perform surgery on/with, just equipment that is sufficiently clean for the brewing process.
Agreed on all points.

I think precision/correctness is always the best side on which to err. While I'm not sure many people will notice the distinction, it's good practice to use the language correctly even if a lot of people don't - just as we do with grammar, for example. Just because a lot of people use something wrongly doesn't make it a truly valid or correct option, any more than "thx 4 ur hlp m8" is proper English just because a lot of people butcher it that way.
If by "conditional merge" you mean a manual retagging and using the [sterilization] tag for questions actually about sterilization, I agree.

@Poshpaws: One can be made a synonym of the other, so people can type both but only one is used. Tags are mainly used for searches, e.g. if you use `[sterilize]` in the search window you get all questions tagged with it. Although the prohibition is on alcohol generally, the poster is not asking about making alcohol generally, but specifically about making beer from a limited selection of ingredients. (E.g. maybe beer is his favorite type of alcohol.) To my mind, if the legal issues were put aside, the question could equally have been "I can't get hold of brewer's yeast, malt or hops, just fresh grains, how can I make beer?" Which I feel would be valid here.

The difference here is that the poster has made it explicitly clear about the situation. Posters from the US typically don't specify their location, so we have simply have to assume they are engaging in making beer legally. The poster specifically states that alcohol is prohibited in his country which puts the onus and responsibility onto this site as to how we treat the question.
sommelier vs brewer, with overlap of course. :)

Personally, I would not use the site. Sites like Beer Advocate and Ratebeer, despite their popularity, have gotten a reputation as a repository of biased opinions and know nothing advice. In order for a similar site here to be successful, it would not only have to distinguish itself from the existing sites, but also be able to deal with those kinds of issues.

@DennyConn What about issues like what you discuss for BJCP? I did not think that would all fly here, I could ask about root cause of a flaw, but asking about comparison of how German and Bohemian Pilsners differ?
@Kortuk - that's a good point. Maybe the issue lies in how we structure, define, and moderate a site like this.
I think that the Alcoholic Beverages would be a better site than something as focused as Beer, from a consumer point of view.
I'm not sure about lumping all alcoholic beverages together - appreciation of wine, mead, beer, vodka, whiskey are quite different.
Perhaps beer appreciation should be removed from this site's scope? Beer appreciation is seldom discussed on this site and would make the distinction between both sites even clearer.

I think folks on the other site might like to 'grok' production. They don't know how to brew beer, but they know something about the water, and maybe something else about the process that might be a sign of quality. They might not know how to make it, but they can talk about some parts of how it's made. I think the context will really set both apart.
One could say that the production of wine and beer are just as different as the consumption of wine and beer. But production of both are in-scope here.

I agree Tim. The same occurred to me. Beer enthusiasts may not need to get into the minutae of brewing, but some understanding of the process is of course important. I've given beer presentations to non-brewing beer consumers, and some of the basics I covered was an overview of the brewing process, ingredients and difference between lager and ale. This site assumes most of that as understood, but I can say that I didn't know it before being a brewer, yet would have liked to know it as a beer consumer. As you say, the context and audience sets it apart.
So you think all alcoholic beverages should be consumed...er subsumed...under one site? Seems strange since often the only thing they have in common is alcohol.

I agree, and would say that we should ideally split this site to exclude wine, mead etc. Neither wine nor mead is brewed so the name homebrewing SE is a misnomer if we really should cover these. This is still a beta site so I hope there is room to shift the definition. My experience is that non-beer related questions have far fewer answers than those that are beer related - I'm sure those experts exist that could answer, but they have not found this site yet. A site like "winemakers" or "vinters" would better suit wine producers, and "meadery" or similar for mead makers.

Yep. Aspects of consumption include acquisition, storage, repercussions, preparation, societal views... While the details may be different, I think that for the most part these aspects aren't awfully dissimilar. (A beer snob isn't that far removed from a wine snob.) And then there's significant overlap once you start talking about mixology.
Not to be argumentative, but what objective aspects of appreciation are different between various forms of alcohol? Perhaps I'm missing something. :)

I'm afraid disagree - I can evaluate beer, but I have far less knowledge to bring to wine evaluation, let alone whiskey or other beverages. The only common element is alcohol, the remainder of the beverage, the way it tastes and is evaluated, stored, served, consumed etc. are distinct. The additional factors you mention, while they are common, you say yourself that the details will be different. E.g. wine storage and aging is very much different from beer storage and aging, with greater differences than overlap.

Regardless of whether or not we allow that proposal to launch into private (or public) beta, whether we allow it to exist long-term will depend *heavily* on whether or not it actually produces something of lasting value. See: [No Artificial Intelligence](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/12/no-artificial-intelligence-in-area-51/) and [When a Site Grows Quiet](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2012/04/when-a-site-grows-quiet/).

Good deal. I think the point (and I think you get it) was that there are still many beer thinkers who feel Ratebeer and BeerAdvocate are producing lasting value, and we don't want these people to become a majority. Of course, I also agree with mdma's thoughts on beer needing distinct sites from wine, etc.; I just think there is a large amount of "pollution" in the beer community, and further that the beer community is easily polluted.

The real test for the site will be: is this able to produce something of higher value than what's already out there on The 'Net. That's definitely not an easy (or particularly objective) test, but it's probably the most important one. FWIW: [*This* site could use a few more self-critical members...](http://meta.homebrew.stackexchange.com/questions/338/lets-get-critical-sep-2013-site-self-evaluation)
